summary: ARIs are one of the major causes of mortality and morbidity in children especially in developing countries. the incidence of influenza-like illness (ILI) is almost similar between developed and developing countries like Nepal. the mortality rates are higher in developing countries. a total of 394 throat swab specimens were collected from children aged two months to 12 years with symptoms of influenza-like illness. of the total, 175 throat swab specimens positive for influenza virus were further tested for detection of other respiratory copathogens. real-time PCR assays were performed for detection of respiratory viruses and other pathogens. nucleic acid was extracted from the throat swab using the PureLinkTM Viral RNA/DNA mini kit. an internal control (IC) was added to each extraction tube. nucleic acid was eluted in 50 l of the elution buffer and stored at 80°C until use. amplification condition includes reverse transcription for 15 minutes at 42°C. denaturation for 3 minutes at 94°C followed by 40 cycles for 8 seconds at 94°C. PCR runs were repeated if a positive and negative control result does not meet the interpretation criteria. the real-time rRT-PCR assay for respiratory pathogens was performed on 7500 Fast Real-Time PCR System (Biomerieux, Luxemburg) an internal control (IC) was added to each extraction tube in order to access the quality of extraction. the extracted nucleic acid was used as a template in each reaction for the FTD Respiratory pathogens 21 multiplex PCR. the thermal cycle amplification condition includes reverse transcription for 15 minutes at 42°C, denaturation for 3 minutes at 94°C, and 40 cycles for 8 seconds at 94°C. PCR runs were repeated if a positive and negative control result does not meet the interpretation criteria. pathogen Influenza A (%) n = 83 Influenza B (%) n = 23 Total positive (%) Rhinovirus 22 (12.6) 4 (2.3) 26 (14.8) RSV A/B 15 (8.6) 4 (2.3) 19 (10.8) Adenovirus 13 (7.4) 1 (0.6) 14 (8.0) Metapneumovirus A/B 4 (2.3) 1 (0.6) 5 (2.9) Bocavirus 2 (1.1) 4 (2.3) 6 (3.4) Enterovirus pathogens Age group (year) Total (%) 5 (%) 6–10 (%) 10–12 (%) RV 10 (5.7) 6 (3.4) 6 (3.4) 22 (12.6) RSV A/B 8 (4.6) 4 (2.3) 3 (1.7) 1 (0.6) 13 (7.4) EV 3 (1.7) 1 (0.6) 1 (0.6) 5 (2.8) MPV A/B 3 (1.7) 1 (0.6) 0 (0.0) 4 (2.3) M. pneumoniae 2 (1.1 coinfections with rhinovirus 10 (5.7%), respiratory syncytial virus A/B 8 (4.6%), adenovirus 9 (5.1%), and coV-HKU1 7 (4.0%) were more common in less than five-year-old children with influenza A compared to influenza B-positive cases. respiratory syncytial virus A/B 4 (2.3%), adenovirus 3 (1.7%), and coV-HKU1 2 virus (1.1%) were comparatively found lower among 6–10 year-old children with influenza A and influenza B respectively. the positive detection rate of influenza A was predominantly found in the month of October 2015 to January 2016 followed by October 2015, respectively. pdm09 + RV + EV 1 (0.6) A/H3 + RV + COR43 3 (1.7) A/H3 + RV + RV + COR43 3 (1.7) A/H3 + RV + RV+ BV 1 (0.6) A/H3 + RV + RSV A/B 2 (1.1) A/H3 + RV + EV 1 (0.6) B + HKU1 + PIV1 1 (0.6) B + RV + COR43 2 (1.1) B a total of 175 influenza-positive specimens were investigated for detection of potential respiratory pathogens from October 2015 to February 2016. of them, the rate of coinfection with rhinovirus, RSV A/B, adenovirus, and CoV-HKU1 viruses was higher. influenza is one of the major public health burdens in developed and developing countries like Nepal. coV-OC43, coV-229E, MPV A-B, bocavirus, enterovirus, and parainfluenza virus 1 and 3 coinfections were found in children infected with influenza. most deaths from pneumonia in children less than 5 years of age occur in developing countries, where information about clinical impact and severity of viral causes is limited. studies have reported both single and multiple respiratory infections in young children (5 year) similar findings have been reported from Brazil, Turkey, Japan, and china. this could be the first study undertaken with multiplex RT-PCR kit. study could not explore clinical pictures in detail, for example, the severity of illness, period of hospital stay, and its outcome among the single and multiple coinfections. findings gave baseline information of respiratory viruses and the distribution pattern within the different age groups of children.
